comments:
Eclipse 3.2RC1

When debugging our Eclipse RCP, Eclipse is unable to locate a class' source code when I click onto a printed stack trace in the console. An error dialog appears with the following message:

Error logged from JDT Debug UI: 
  Unable to access archive C:\Eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.platform.source_3.0.1\src\org.eclipse.platform_3.0.1\startupsrc.zip

Please note that my Eclipse installation is located at a completely different spot. Here's the stack trace from the error log:

Can you describe your setup? i.e. What do you mean by "my Eclipse installation is located at a completely different spot"

Well, I meant that I didn't put my Eclipse into c:\Eclipse, so I am not sure where that path originates from. The source code locations in the PDE preferences also don't show any such path.

Having said that, I just found the culprit. The launch configuration I use (of type org.eclipse.pde.ui.RuntimeWorkbench) is a shared one and at its very top it contains that path within the org.eclipse.debug.core.source_locator_memento element. However, I've got no idea how it came there nor how to remove it without manually editing the launch configuration.

Please also note that this was an Eclipse 3.1 share launch configuration that's stored in our SCM.
Check on the "Source Lookup" tab of the launch config to see if the zip in question appears there.
There is no "Source Lookup" tab for the Eclipse runtime launcher anymore...
Sounds like on old config that has an old source locator that you can no longer edit.

right.  In the case of something left in the console, PDE delegates to the default source lookup guy as there is no classloader to query.  

Leaving the source tab in is/was not an option, as it would give people the false idea that they have control over the source lookup which they don't.

This console stack trace is a case that Darin had forecasted, and the default source lookup seemed not worse than the result the user had before the new PDE source lookup director was installed.
I think the fix is to create a new launch config with the 3.2 tooling. Perhaps PDE should destory old launch config settings for configs with old source locators?
Darin, we still need the old source locator to delegate to it in case the new PDE lookup director fails, right?
OK, but shouldn't its path be updated then?

ok, there are multiple duplicates of this defect, and yet no one replied to comment 17.

If people want to see this one fixed, they either have to provide a .launch file on which the problem occurs or provide details on what version of Eclipse these launch configurations are created.

I was duplicating a java application config that was created by 3.1.2 (release).
So im not sure, but physically created it was by the 3.2.0 (release).

Here is a launch file i run as java application
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<launchConfiguration type="org.eclipse.jdt.launching.localJavaApplication">
<booleanAttribute key="org.eclipse.debug.ui.ATTR_LAUNCH_IN_BACKGROUND" value="false"/>
<stringAttribute key="org.eclipse.jdt.launching.MAIN_TYPE" value="de.own.client.swing.Main"/>
<booleanAttribute key="org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui.INCLUDE_EXTERNAL_JARS" value="true"/>

<listEntry value="4"/>
</listAttribute>
<stringAttribute key="org.eclipse.jdt.launching.PROGRAM_ARGUMENTS" value="-l./lib/themes/coronaHthemepack.zip"/>
<stringAttribute key="org.eclipse.jdt.launching.PROJECT_ATTR" value="catplan"/>
<stringAttribute key="org.eclipse.jdt.launching.VM_ARGUMENTS" value="-Dde.own.system.properties=./config/client.properties -Djava.
util.logging.config.file=./config/clientLogging.properties -ea"/>
<listAttribute key="org.eclipse.debug.core.MAPPED_RESOURCE_PATHS">
<listEntry value="/catplan"/>
</listAttribute>
<booleanAttribute key="org.eclipse.debug.core.appendEnvironmentVariables" value="true"/>
</launchConfiguration>
Darin, this is a pure Java launch config.  Are you sure all these duplicates are for Eclipse Application launch configs?  Could there be a problem at the Platform/JDT Debug level?
From comment#21, does the Java project referenced in the config ("catplan"), refer to a non-existant Junit on it's buildpath?

If i look into Run -> Java Application "catplan-client" -> Tab "Source"
there is under the treenode "Default" an entry 
junitsrc.zip /home/user/Programme/eclipse/...
                  ...plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.source_3.1.1/src/org.junit_3.8.1
If i click this item the add / remove buttons on side are disabled. Thus i cannot remove the entry.

The "Default" entry refers to the "default source lookup path" which is a single non-editable entry. The defualt source lookup path reflects your runtime classpath, which is inferred from your project's build path. Is Junit3.8.1 on your project buildpath (project > properties > buildpath)?

Yes it is:
JUNIT_HOME/junit.jar - /home/user/Programme/eclipse/plugins/org.junit_3.8.1/junit.jar
This node contains in Source attachment:
ECLIPSE_HOME/plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.source_3.1.1/src/org.junit_3.8.1/junitsrc.zip
- /home/user/Programme/eclipse/...
          ...plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.source_3.1.1/src/org.junit_3.8.1/junitsrc.zip

In the dialog for edit this entry there is a message, that the path "/home/user/Programme/eclipse/...
      ...plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.source_3.1.1/src/org.junit_3.8.1/junitsrc.zip" not exists.

I think i can remember, that i've added the junitsrc.zip to the eclipse variables manually (For debugging issues). Is it possible that this causes the problems. I did it not for the new 3.2.0 release. But why is the click in the console causing this error dialog? I think its not relevant for viewing my source.

Created an attachment (id=46323)
Pre 3.2 shared launch config 

This shared config gives the same junit src error when trying to view src from console messages and when using the debug "Display" feature to investigate basic JDK classes like String or HashMap
If anybody encountered such a problem with an "Eclipse Application" launch configuration, please attach it.  Thanks.
I removed the source attachment (see #26) and now i can click the links and appropriate source file is opened.

I am using Eclipse 3.2 with WTP 1.5 and the builtin JUNIT_HOME variable configuration is set to /opt/eclipse_3.2_WTP1.5/plugins/org.junit_3.8.1 but its Source Attachment location (as visible under Build Path config for JUNIT_HOME) is set to ECLIPSE_HOME/plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.source_3.1.1/src/org.junit_3.8.1/junitsrc.zip

This is incorrect for Eclipse 3.2, the location of this file is really:

ECLIPSE_HOME/plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.source_3.2.0.v20060609m-F7snq1fxia-Z4XP/src/org.junit_3.8.1/junitsrc.zip
re comment 31, I suggest opening a separate bug for the JUnit problem against JDT/UI

Inspite of comment #25, I can edit this value like any other property.  I have reconfigured my buildpath to make use of JUNIT_SRC_HOME/junitsrc.zip which I hope is the correct fix for me and future proof.

Inline with comment #27, the source lookup functionaility should not fail fast when encountering the first error.  It would be preferable to consider the problem a WARNING and not a FATAL ERROR which inhibits source lookup from taking place at all.  Especially when the file we are looking for probablyt isn't in the missing ZIP file anyway.


Hoky-doky the REAL error here is the use of:

Configure Build Path -> Libaries [tab] -> Add Libraries -> Select "JUnit"

The configured Source Attachment is not using JUNIT_SRC_HOME.
Issue raised re comment #32 and #33 in  https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=150961

I have fixed JDT Debug as follows:

* Rather than an error, a warning dialog is displayed when source cannot be found and an archive is missing

The following behavior was already present in 3.2:

* The dialog only appears if source cannot be found and an exception occurrs.
* If there is an invalid archive on the source lookup path, but source is found, no error dialog appears.

Bug 150961 against JDT UI addresses the migration issue for JUNIT_SRC_HOME
Darin, I am moving to your bucket, since, as it stands, there is no work to be done on the PDE side.
Fixed.
Please verify, Mike.

I'm coming from Bug# 136592 https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=136592, which I mis-commented on:

summary:
my Steps to Reproduce:  (comment 9)
 create a project
  add a library (e.g. foo.jar)
  add a source library to above library (e.g. bar.zip)
  create an app that throws an exception and creates a console stacktrace (does not need to involve classes in above jar)
  run app
  click on an element in the stacktrace - works fine
  delete library from filesystem, but not build path
  you may need to close, delete the file, and reopen the project
  re-run app
  click on an element in the stacktrace - failure, popup with details indicating source folder is missing.

See Davin's response, in 136592, comment #10, https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=136592#c10.

I see the above (this bug, 138877) resolution, and just want to add the comments here to be sure no information is lost.  I can see how on the implementation side the problems I experienced could be one and the same as this bug, but my steps to reproduce were not identical.

I'll also prefix this that I see there is a fix for this already mentioned, and I actually assume it fixes this - it looks alright - but I'm writing this as if it didn't.  Again, completeness and the additional reasons that follow.

> The problem in comment#9 is expected - i.e.
> you've clicked on a stack trace for which the source has been deleted, and you
> get told that an archive is missing.

It may be expected, but it is still wrong - the code I clicked on had nothing to do with the file missing in the build path.  Essentially, despite the fact there was a valid hit in the existing source, we acted as if there was no match and showed the error.  

This makes clicking in the console output _useless_ and unusable until I debug my source path.  To do so, I have to hunt through my various projects's build paths looking for libraries' dangling source elements, close and reopen the projects, dance in circles and then jangle a little bit of bat guano, just in order to look at a file which I DO readily have access to and is not related to my source problem.  

Even falling back to the byte-code depiction of the class in the library would be preferable, and that would be a good time to show the warning that the source attachment is invalid.

> Note that we've improved the error reporting for missing source when an archive
> goes missing in 3.3 - see bug 138877. The user simply gets a warning now, and
> nothing is written to the error log.

You state, "error reporting for missing source when an archive goes missing" - that's not my case.  Just to be clear, the case I'm describing is, "the source goes missing for a valid archive".

I have to say this bug is really irritating, especially since it is much more reproducible than the phantom-Console-which-won't-go-away bug (that bothered me infrequently from 3.0M3 through to 3.2RC4, last time I saw it).  If there is a 3.2.1, and this fixes my issue, I'd really vote this fix to be back-ported. (FWIW! :-))

This is of course intended as a constructive contribution, if I seem less than so, it really is the irritation with the bug and, of course, not the developers.
apologies :  Davin should be Darin.  Also, poorly cross-referenced comments in the other issue, sorry about that.  You'd think eclipse could use Jira.  ;-)
*** Bug 141546 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

+1 for a backport from me (I don't know where else to do it)
Thanks!
Jim

Please backport it to 3.2 as it really makes debugging impossible, and though I enjoy the occaissional dance around my desk, my co-workers look at me in funny ways for days when I do so...

IMO, when there are so many duplicates, then a lot of people encounter this problem.

Debug has fixed the following (in 3.3) - we no longer report/log an error when source cannot be found *and* an arhcive goes missing. Instead, we simply offer an "warning" dialog saying that source could not be found, and there is a missing archive. 

NOTE: We do not fail/abort source lookup when a source path contains one missing archive - we search the entire path for source even if one or more archives are missing. I've tested various scenarios to confirm this. We only report an error if the entire path is searched *and* source cannot be found *and* at least one archive is missing.

I do not think this fix will address the problem that most people are encountering. It looks like people are really encountering the problem of a broken build path when migrating from 3.1 to 3.2, and the location of JUnit changing.

See bug 150961.

For this reason, I don't think releasing the "fix" for this problem will really be a help in 3.2.1.

I also could not get this problem to happen with any regularity, but with the conditions described in the previous comment, I have not seen an error since.

marking as verified, if the problem surfaces again by all means reopen.

I have been plagued by this problem ever since Eclipse 3.2 was released.  The whole time I was convinced it was an Eclipse bug, but it isn't.

I work on a project with several other developers who also use Eclipse.  We keep the .classpath file under version control so that we can share it.  This .classpath file had a reference to the old Eclipse 3.1 path for junitsrc.zip.  Once I updated this to point to the correct path in the Eclipse 3.2 installation, things started working again!

I hope this helps others that have been going crazy with the same issue.

- Mike

If you update eclipse, it does not update your project settings (.classpath, ...). If you got there some links, e.g.,

<classpathentry kind="var" path="JUNIT_HOME/junit.jar" sourcepath="ECLIPSE_HOME/plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.source_3.1.1/src/org.junit_3.8.1/junitsrc.zip"/>

Pointing to locations, which dont exist after the update, you might experience problems.

So check your project settings, and update the path.

Workaround for 3.2:
 
- Recursively search for the term "junitsrc.zip" in all .classpath files. I used an external editor but Eclipse itself should work just fine.
- Delete all lines containing the text
- Search again to make sure they are all removed.
- Clean/rebuild the entire workspace
- Fix any projects that need fixing - I had some that had lost all build path settings

This worked for me. I had searched for junitsrc.zip in the entire eclipse directory + workspaces, but only found entries in the .classpath files. I got the same error message as above, but the error message did not mention which of the dependent projects the error was in.

traces.message: The system cannot find the path specified
